where do you want to start i want to

that you hear this so make sure that

before you tune your hyper parameters
and i see people screw this up
quite often right you kind of jump past
the step where your model isn't working
and actually when you find out there's a

it's going to invalidate all your hyper
parameter tuning and i think andre
carpathi has the best resource by far
on this and he recommends choosing the
simplest possible model
and the simplest set of data in fact
trying to overfit on a single batch
as the first test that your model's
effective and then sort of progressing
slowly through
making your model more and more
complicated and you start being sure
that your model is performing the way
you expect it and then i think there's
another step which is that you want to
explore the data before you try to
what's called exploit or find the very
best possible set of hyper parameters
and so you typically want to try hyper
parameters by hand try a wide set of
possible values
build an intuition for what they do and
they use sort of a course defined method
where you start off with kind of
a wide swath of values and slowly refine
to more and more specific values
and then finally at every step it's
important to ask yourself am i over
fitting or under fitting because you'd
want to do opposite things
so by overfitting i mean that your
performance on the training data
is higher than your performance on the
test data and if that's the case
then everything you do to make your
model more complicated is going to make
it worse
so if you're over fitting you want to
make your model simpler you want to find
more training data
or you want to add regularization like
dropout
now if you're under fitting and by that
i mean that your model is performing
about the same on your training data
and your test data or validation data
then you have the chance to make your
model more complicated and more powerful
so you might want to
explore more things like model
architecture
i think that is quite important to build

there's sort of three traditional

the kind of basic three strategies that

random which is also incredibly simple
and then bayesian which is much more

and one of the things that everyone

although i think ray tune makes it easy

so grid search is something that you
might guess
is a strategy you might come up with on
your own which is you basically take
a discrete set of things to try for each
hyper parameter that you
have and then try every combination of
those parameters
so it's very very simple to implement it
works really well
it's it's very systematic so it's easy
to kind of do analysis to find

what hyper parameters are effective and
not effective but it can get very

you know you have basically um you
multiply together every number of

every hyper parameter and that number

random searches may be even simpler than

it's actually easier
to do in a distributed fashion and it

hyper parameters but i think people use

there's always an intuition here which i

some strategy called hyperband and
there's a great paper that came out

and this comes from the intuition that
over time
models that perform poorly in the
beginning tend to perform poorly after
lots of training data
so the strategy is to run the training
for a set number of iterations
often epics or sets of training data and
then you basically take the top
fraction of models usually it's
one-third of the top quarter the models
and you let them run for another set
of steps and then you once again take
the top third or quarter of the models
and you let those
run for a few more steps and then um
finally you're left with maybe just one
or two models that you
let run to the end and while the
bayesian optimization
tends to give you maybe a 2x factor
improvement the hyperband
can give you more like a 10x factor of
improvement so hyperband the effects are
not subtle
it's very efficient and people should do
